@graph.name: How to Implement Canonical Tags in Shopify
@graph.description: Step-by-step guide to setting up and managing canonical URLs in Shopify stores

step.name: Access Shopify Admin
step.text: Log into your Shopify Admin Dashboard and navigate to Online Store > Themes > Edit Code

step.name: Locate Theme File
step.text: Open the theme.liquid file or relevant template file for the page you want to modify

step.name: Insert Canonical Tag
step.text: Add the canonical URL between the <head></head> HTML code section using <link rel="canonical" href="{{ canonical_url }}">

step.name: Audit Implementation
step.text: Use Google Search Console or Screaming Frog to verify canonical tags are correctly implemented

mainEntity.name: Can I use canonical tags to link pages between different Shopify stores?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, canonical tags are meant to identify the preferred URL within the same store. Linking pages between different Shopify stores with canonical tags is not recommended, as each store should have its own unique URLs and content hierarchy.

mainEntity.name: Do canonical tags impact page load speed on Shopify?

acceptedAnswer.text: No, canonical tags are simple HTML link elements that do not impact page load speed. They are processed by search engines but do not slow down the rendering of the page for users.

mainEntity.name: Can I set canonical tags for paginated collection pages in Shopify?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, Shopify allows you to set canonical tags for paginated collection pages. Typically, the canonical tag should point to the first page of the collection, ensuring that Google treats it as the main URL for indexing.

mainEntity.name: Are canonical tags necessary for blog posts in Shopify?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, canonical tags are important for blog posts, especially if they are published across multiple URLs or categories. By setting the preferred URL for each blog post, you ensure that search engines correctly identify the primary version.

hasDefinedTerm.name: Canonical Tag
hasDefinedTerm.description: An HTML link element that helps search engines understand which version of a web page is the original or master copy

hasDefinedTerm.name: Canonical URL
hasDefinedTerm.description: The preferred URL that should be considered the authoritative source for a particular piece of content

hasDefinedTerm.name: Duplicate Content
hasDefinedTerm.description: Multiple URLs displaying identical or highly similar content that can dilute SEO value

hasDefinedTerm.name: Noindex Tag
hasDefinedTerm.description: An HTML meta tag that tells search engines not to index a specific page
